author: ednoepel
content: Could someone explain why mining nodes (seemingly) only consider gas for the next nonce rather than total gas of an EOA's TX queue?  [This TX queue](https://etherscan.io/address/0x23983ea2123d40eb5655dfff3f3c917c78f214f6)  seems beneficial to include in a block; two 100,000gwei TXes from yesterday are being held back by several sub-50gwei TXes from two days ago.

author: timbeiko
content: Itâ€™s just harder for nodes to compute this than on, say, Bitcoin

author: pietjepuk
content:
The earliest tx in that pending queue is not eligible for inclusion, and has not been for the last two days ( https://etherscan.io/tx/0xe5f978ffaccd6c77c487a923c9e6d775ad454a92c993a16d0fdb97c0ca529697 ).
Its gas price is 23.31 Gwei, and the base fee hasn't gone that low from what I can tell.

author: 0xsadcat
content: what happens if previous tx invalidates the next one? this could lead to dos attacks on block building

author: 0xsadcat
content: although as there's no eth pull mechanism it could be included by assuming all previous tx spend all their msg.value (no refunds) <:peepothink2:754852084121206824>
